Name: Aïn Telata
OtherTribes: Beni Hassen;Ouled Hedim;Ouled Hamza;Emfata;Ouled Maaref;Titteri;Zenakhera;Rahman;Ouled Mokhtar;Abid

Name: Djebel el Heuch

Comments: Said to be frequented by all the Kabyle tribes from the nearby mountains.

Name: Sebt el Bellout
Comments: Held on the beylik farm on right bank of Chelif.

Name: Oued el Ahd
OtherTribes: Ouled Si Amer;Ouled Si Moussa;Ouled Si Aïssa

Name: Telata
Comments: An annual (rather than weekly) spring market particularly for the Ouled Naïl lasting 5-6 weeks. Where Oulad Mokhtar have their winter villag of stone houss, grain stores and som arabl fields (seems to be prior to sharper distinction of the eastern group known from th sio surveys)

Name: Amoura
OtherTribes: Ouled Hamza;Emfata;Ouled Maaref;Ouled Ahmed;El Abadlia;Rahman;Ouled Mokhtar
Hassen ben Ali;Ouled Sidi Ahmed ben Youssef;Ouled Meriam

Name: Souk el Had
OtherTribes: Hassen ben Ali;Ouled Sidi Ahmed ben Youssef
Comments: in the territory of the Beni Silem
in the territory of the Mellouan

OtherTribes: Ouled Si Aïssa;Deïmat;Souari;Titteri;Ouled Mokhtar;Ouled Sidi Ahmed ben Youssef
Comments: The location of this market moves with the tribe.

Name: Saneg
Comments: According to Urbain in 1843, larger families of the Ouled Mokhtar (Gheraba?) have their winter camps here and cultivate a little cereal nearby, having built a few stone houses and granaries. This is supposed to be also the location where the annual market of the Ouled Naïl was for 5-6 weeks and the their heussa tax was taken, but it is not clear if spoken of as something in the past tense and mostly associated with pre-1830 Ottoman period or that it ceased under Abdelkader and then was revived post-revolt. Bernard and Lacroix (1906: 87 fn.3) state the Ouled Naïl paid 100,000 francs of heussa tax here in the Ottoman period.

Name: Serouan
Comments: Mentioned in 1813 as a camp for Larbaa and various other tribes and a place where the heussa was paid. Mentioned again in 1825 as a camp for buying grain. Mentioned as a camp for one group from the Larbaa tribe in 1851.

Name: Aïn Telata
Comments: Mentioned as a camp for one group from the Larbaa tribe in 1851.

Name: Aïn Bareda
Comments: Mentioned in 18125 as a campsite for buying grain (Oulad Dhya fraction of Ouled Naïl).

Name: Oued Moudjehial
Comments: Mentioned in 1851 as a camp for part of the Larbaa and in 1855 as a place where they sometimes paid the heussa tax.
